external_url: The Future of Supply Chain Sustainability
name: 2019-06-04T16:30:00-0700
venue_id: The IoES Corporate Partners Program is hosting a panel of three business professionals on the topic of supply chain sustainability. Incorporating supply chain considerations is no longer a differentiator in the field of corporate sustainability, but rather a standard practice for major companies. During the discussion, speakers will address topics such as procurement strategies, supplier evaluations, and the future of supply chain practices. Three student teams will share their research findings on related topics during a networking reception following the event. Program: 4:30-6:00 Speakers and Panel Discussion 6:00-7:00 Reception with Light Refreshments, Student Posters Parking will be provided in Structure 5 for registered attendees. Detailed campus map will be included an a reminder email on May 31st.  Panelists: Daniel Perry, Global Alliances Director @ EcoVadis Shawn O'Connell, President, Motive Power-Americas @ EnerSys Cynthia Holmes, Director of Trademarks & Licensing @ ASUCLA To learn more about the Corporate Partners Program at IoES, visit our webpage: https://www.ioes.ucla.edu/cpp/.

name: 2019-06-20T14:00:00-0700
venue_id: This workshop will provide an introduction to peer reviewing for early career researchers, including graduate students. The workshop will cover best practices and a mock review. Becoming a better reviewer will help you to become a better author and to hone some of the skills central to scientific success, including critical thinking, evaluating research, providing helpful feedback, and understanding the mindset and expectations of peer reviewers and editors.

name: 2019-06-28T16:00:00-0700
venue_id: It's our Moon Sisters' Soil2Soul Retreat! This woman-centric newMOON Shabbaton is a retreat that celebrates diversity of expression and experience and we actively welcome queer and transwomen to join us, as well as non-binary individuals. Together we will enjoy an unforgettable Shabbat as we explore Jewish mystical teachings and a deep and embodied connection to Oneness in a non-hierarchical and sacred space. Give and receive lifeforce as we reflect on our ancestors, our connection to the land, and the unique Torah that each one of us has to share with this world.  Join us for ritual, challah kneading and baking, healing workshops, and shhhh, a newMOON dance party! Enjoy healthy, homecooked always-organic food throughout the weekend.  Optional: sleep outside in a tent, under the mysterious dark moon!

name: 2019-06-20T08:00:00-0700
venue_id: The theme for this year’s 2018 RCMAR Annual Investigators meeting is Looking Forward: A Bigger and Better RCMAR. This meeting will bring together the latest findings in minority aging research. Through plenary presentations, conversations with experts, networking and work group meetings, attendees will gain a wealth of new information and the infrastructure to support long-term mentoring relationships. The deadline for registering for the annual meeting is Monday, June 10, 2019. LOCATION: The annual meeting is scheduled to take place on June 20-21 at the UCLA Meyer and Renee Luskin Conference Center located at 425 Westwood Plaza, Los Angeles, CA. ANNUAL MEETING FEES AND REGISTRATION: The cost to attend the meeting is $90, (plus a $7.07 Eventbrite service fee), and includes the following: Welcome Reception and Poster Presentations at the UCLA Meyer and Renee Luskin Conference Center on June 19 from 6-8 pm. Buffet Lunch and Afternoon Snacks on June 20th  Breakfast, Buffet Lunch and Afternoon Snacks on June 21st. WELCOME RECEPTION & POSTER PRESENTATIONS (JUNE 19, 6-8 pm): A Welcome Reception will be held at UCLA Meyer and Renee Luskin Conference Center in Legacy AB meeting room on June 20 from 6-8 pm. In addition to networking during the reception, Scientists will also have the opportunity to view Poster Presentations. Appetizers will be served. Note: There will be a no host bar available that can accept only credit card payments (no cash or other forms of payment).  OPTIONAL GRANT WRITING WORKSHOP (JUNE 20, 8 am - noon): This optional workshop will take place on June 20th from 8 am – noon (before the annual meeting). Participants are limited to a max of 2 Scientists per site. The cost to attend is $30 (plus a $3.46 Eventbrite service fee) and will emphasize the skills, tips and tricks to help Scientists successfully apply for grants. Prior to registering, the Coordinating Center is requesting the following be emailed to rcmar@ucla.edu: the Scientist’s name, their email address, and title of their project and a brief statement of what aspect of the proposal they would like to focus on (e.g. aims, methods, overall approach, response to reviewer comments, etc.). Additionally individuals who are not ready to submit something for review but who want to hear the talks and observe the review process may register by using the (Waitlist Observer registration) provided they agree to observe and provide constructive feedback on reviewed grants as appropriate. SUBMIT AN ABSTRACT: Directors are asked to identify ONE Scientist to present on their unfinished works in progress" during our Breakout Presentations on June 21. Additionally Directors can identify up to ONE Scientist to present in our Poster Presentations (During Welcome Reception on June 19). Note: The Poster Presentations are optional. Once the Scientist is confirmed

external_url: Doc Screening: THE REST I MAKE UP about playwright Maria Irene Fornes
name: 2019-06-05T19:00:00-0700
venue_id: Special Screening: The Rest I Make Up As part of her residency at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television (UCLA TFT), join Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Paula Vogel, the School’s inaugural Hearst Theater Lab Distinguished Visiting Playwright-in-Residence, as she presents director Michelle Memran’s film The Rest I Make Up, a 2018 documentary about award-winning experimental playwright and director María Irene Fornés, at the James Bridges Theater at UCLA TFT. Fornés, a Cuban-American playwright who began her career in the early 1960s in New York City, was known for her passionate, unrelenting and empathetic investigation of the human condition, particularly the way personal relationships were shaped by economic conditions. She passed away in 2018 at the age of 88. Director Memran began interviewing Fornés on-camera in 2003, capturing her iconoclastic personality, approach to art and leadership role in the off-off-Broadway movement of the 1960s. Fornés was as famous for her teaching as she was for her writing and in The Rest I Make Up, she shares her methodology for tapping into the unconscious creativity that fueled her ferocious work. Screening Post-show conversation with Paula Vogel, Michelle Memran and TFT Associate Dean, Edit Villarreal Reception Doors open at 6:30 p.m.  Parking is available in Lot 3 for $12.   This event is co-sponsored by the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television and the L.A. Playwrights Union.

external_url: James Dean America: Screenplay Live Read Benefiting Young Storytellers
name: 2019-06-01T14:00:00-0700
venue_id: James Dean AmericaWritten by UCLA Staff Member, Joseph Mango Starring Jake Borelli, Sharif Atkins, Marguerite Moreau, Stephen Macht, Michael Durrell, Miranda Wynne, Ashley Romans, Ryan Brophy, and Landon Tavernier. In 1955, America lost its Rebel. In 2003, Edwin Donovan changed the story. James Dean America is a heartwarming comedy-drama about the the power of stories, the magic of the movies, and the impact of empathy as well as a little tribute to one of UCLA's most famous students, James Dean.  In 2003, a wide-eyed producer's assistant stumbles upon a gem of a script that was to star James Dean before the fatal car crash, so he tracks down the cantankerous screenwriter (now in his 70s) who refuses to sell the script without the blessing of James Dean whom he swears is still alive. Join us for a fun, engaging afternoon to benefit the awesome non-profit Young Storytellers which provides mentorship to students in low-income schools on how to write stories and discover the power of their voice.  A student's short script will be performed before the reading.  All ticket proceeds will go to Young Storytellers. We look forward to seeing you at the movies...we mean the live-read! Your donations and support are truly appreciated! Presented by the UCLA Semel Institute Center for Health Services and Society's HEArts Program (Healing and Education through the Arts) and UCLA Health   FAQs   Are there minimum age requirements to enter the event? If we had to give the screenplay a rating, it would probably be on the cusp of PG-13 for one scene that has brief strong language and some instances of mild language.   What are my parking options for getting to and from the event? We recommend parking at Structure 3 which is located right next to the theater for a rate $3 per hour or $12 all day.  Just make sure you pay for parking at the kiosk first before going to the theater.  You may pay via the parking app by downloading the ParkMobile App from your phone's App Store and using parking zone 2505.   How can I contact the organizer with any questions? Feel free to e-mail us at jmango@ucla.edu   Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event? We definitely understand that hardly anyone owns a printer these days, so there's no need to print your ticket(s).  Feel free to show the ticket on your phone or simply check in with your name.   Is my registration fee or ticket transferrable? If you'd like to transfer your ticket to someone else, just e-mail us at jmango@ucla.edu and let us know whose name you'd like the ticket to go under.   What can I bring into the event? We love popcorn, candy, and sodas at the movies, err live-read, as much as the next person, but unfortunately no food or drinks are allowed inside the auditorium, but we hope you'll be inspired to go see a movie! If you made it this far, how about some trivia:  James Bridges, the person the theater is named after, was a big James Dean fan, so much that he wrote and directed a film titled September 30, 1955 which follows a college student impacted by the death of James Dean.

name: 2019-06-12T14:00:00-0700
venue_id: What is a Creative Passport? Artists, songwriters, producers, engineers – in short – music makers: How does someone - fan or business - search for you online today? Where do they go to find you? How would a brand, a film, a commercial or an app with a budget for a song go about getting in touch with you to use a track you wrote or were involved in? Are you aware that about 1/4 of a $45 billion industry gets paid to the wrong person/organisation or not at all due to missing data? Currently all information pertaining who we are as music makers - our discographies, biographies, press kits, IDs, contacts, representation, etc in short: our data - is currently uploaded and stored all over the place online and not necessarily by us, creating a huge data mess complicating the admin process like getting paid and resulting in missed opportunities, monies and collaborations. So what is the solution? Spearheaded by Imogen Heap working with other music makers and technologists, we have created The Creative Passport – a digital identity container - which would hold all information about you as a music maker. Like an IMdB + Linkedin for music if you like. With all our information in one place, we would gain visibility through search-ability, streamline time-consuming admin and likely aid the process in getting paid quicker and more fairly with new income streams and opportunities arising as well. Why come to this event? For the Creative Passport to be effective however we need music makers around the world to sign up to it, so we are hosting forums where you as music-makers can input into the development of The Creative Passport. We will share our vision of how we hope it will evolve, exchange ideas and have an open dialogue and together, we can work to shape the Creative Passport into what we need it to be. As part of these forums, we will also have the first beta version of the Creative Passport app available to download and test together and share with other music makers. So if you want to be part of the Mycelia family and to be in a position where you transform the industry for good, then sign up and share the invite with your colleagues/collaborators/friends!

external_url: Phir Se Samm Pe Aana (\Returning to the First Beat\") — Documentary Screening"
name: 2019-06-08T14:30:00-0700
venue_id: Phir Se Samm Pe Aana (“Returning to the First Beat”) Surabhi Sharma, Director; Sharma and Dr. Tejaswini Niranjana, Producers 2017 (85 mins) The metropolitan transformation of Bombay in the nineteenth and twentieth century kept time with changes in the practice and pedagogy of Hindustani classical music in the city. With the decline of princely states’ traditional patronage systems, musicians, among others, began to gravitate to the rapidly growing colonial city of Bombay, in search of new sponsors. This led, in turn, to the formation of a distinctive audience for Hindustani sangeet in the city – one not limited to the princely courts and exclusive homes of the aristocracy. Phir se samm pe aana strives to experience the space for Hindustani classical music in Bombay. The film revisits the sites clustered in and around Girgaon, which was part of the native town of the colonial city and was one of the key neighborhoods where singers, patrons, and the audiences lived. The film seeks to understand the musical legacy of this neighborhood, even as it reimagines the documentary mode. This film ‘listens’ to architectural structures in an attempt to reflect on the deep history of this practice. In narrativising the love of music that took shape in this neighborhood, we also seek to experience ‘film time’ rather than evoke a time past or record the present. The film seeks repetition and cyclical time to imagine a narrative on music. Phir se…is an opportunity to experience an interior, almost intimate practice of the musical form. This film emerged from a collaborative research project of Surabhi Sharma and Dr. Tejaswini Niranjana, aimed at understanding Hindustani classical music as part of the intangible urban history of the metropolis of Bombay/Mumbai. Presented by The Mohindar Brar Sambhi Endowed Chair in Indian Music and The UCLA Center for India and South Asia (CISA)

external_url: Madly in Love with Music: Hindustani Sangeet in 20th Century Mumbai
name: 2019-06-08T16:30:00-0700
venue_id: MADLY IN LOVE WITH MUSIC: Hindustani Sangeet in 20th Century Mumbai Lecture by Tejaswini Niranjana Love and madness come together in the metropolis as a condition of subjective excess, the condition of the musical subject’s simultaneous psychic and social habitation of modern urban space. This talk focuses on the manifestations of musicophilia in Mumbai from the late 19th century to the present. Niranjana proposes that this phenomenon of music-loving, and the concept of a lingua musica, help us grasp the workings of the metropolitan unconscious of a large colonial port-city like Mumbai, throwing new light on issues of the subjective and the social. Tejaswini Niranjana is currently Professor and Head, Department of Cultural Studies, Lingnan University, Hong Kong. She is also Visiting Professor with the School of Arts and Science at Ahmedabad University, India. She is co-founder of the Centre for the Study of Culture and Society, Bangalore, which offered an innovative inter-disciplinary PhD programme from 2000-2012. During 2012-16, she headed the Centre for Indian Languages in Higher Education at the Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, and was Indian-language advisor to Wikipedia. She is the author of Siting Translation: History, Post-structuralism and the Colonial Context (Berkeley, 1992), Mobilizing India: Women, Music and Migration between India and Trinidad (Durham, 2006), and Musicophilia in Mumbai (forthcoming in 2019). Among her edited volumes is Genealogies of the Asian Present: Situating Inter-Asia Cultural Studies (Delhi, 2015), with Wang Xiaoming. Reception follows in the Green Room (1230). Presented by The Mohindar Brar Sambhi Endowed Chair in Indian Music and The UCLA Center for India and South Asia (CISA)

external_url: Mural Launch & Music at W Los Angeles - West Beverly Hills with KiriLeigh Jones
name: 2019-06-20T20:00:00-0700
venue_id: ABOUT THE EVENTJoin us Thursday June 20th @ W Los Angeles - West Beverly Hills' Living Room Bar for #REPRISE -- a free to attend monthly event featuring what's new + next in music, art, and fashion. Presented by December 9th, this month's event features the launch of a mural by KiriLeigh Jones, with work on display, DJ set and live music (TBA). ABOUT KIRILEIGH JONESKiriLeigh Jones is a self-taught artist raised in the Bay Area of California. She picked up small, detailed illustration while working as a nail artist in San Francisco before relocating to Denver where it evolved from nails to mandala style art on paper. KiriLeigh started painting murals when a good friend asked her to paint a logo on the wall at their freshly renovated studio and it progressed from there. Whether it’s a wall mural or a sketch on paper, her goal is to create an experience through her art.  ABOUT DECEMBER 9THDecember 9th is a Los Angeles-based creative agency built to support artists through the various steps of their careers. Through exhibitions, work-for-hire opportunities and sales support, December 9th builds channels for artists to keep working. December 9th is passionate about art, and is dedicated to creating a company that truly benefits artists.

name: 2019-06-02T08:50:00-0700
venue_id: **Please read the entire course description before making a purchase.** COURSE DESCRIPTION According to the American Heart Association, the Heartsaver CPR course is “designed for anyone with little or no medical training who needs a course completion card for job, regulatory, or other requirements.” We highly encourage all members of our community to pursue this basic CPR training, especially those who work in large public places or those who spend much time with multiple age ranges. Students practice as they learn under the observation of the instructors, which allows them to receive feedback and guidance. At the end of the four-hour class, students will need to pass skills examinations for both adult/child and infant CPR to receive their certification. *This course is taught in English Content covered by the course (from AHA): High-quality CPR for adults, children, and infants The AHA Chain of Survival Use of an AED Choking relief for adults, children, and infants REFUND POLICY We will refund your ticket in full if requested at least 48 hours prior to the start of class. Requests for refunds that are not within this time frame will be denied. PARKING INFORMATION The UCLA campus provides a number of pay by space parking lots that are easily accessible. Lots 4, 7, 8 and 9 are all located relatively close to our normal classrooms in Ackerman Union and the Student Activities Center (SAC). These parking lots can be located through any map of UCLA. Our program is not responsible for any parking-related issues. MISCELLANEOUS To receive a certification, students must demonstrate proficiency on both the skills taught and the conceptual content of the course. That is, instructors must have confidence that the student can physically perform high-quality CPR and that the student is able to answer any questions regarding the content covered in class. If you are unsure if these two requirements can be met due to a physical barrier or a language barrier, please contact us at our email (below) before purchasing a ticket. For more information, please refer to our website: http://uclacpr.weebly.com/ If you have any additional questions/concerns, feel free to email us at uclacpr@gmail.com

external_url: Niarchos Foundation Center & Los Angeles Greek Film Festival
name: 2019-06-03T19:00:00-0700
venue_id: DAY 1 | Opening Night | Monday, June 3rd The successful collaboration between UCLA Stavros Niarchos Foundation Center for the Study of Hellenic Culture and Los Angeles Greek Film Festival continues for a second year with another unique event. The premiere screening of The Right Pocket of the Robe by first-time feature film director Yiannis Lapatas will open LAGFF at the UCLA on Monday, June 3, at 7 pm.  Parking is available at UCLA in Parking Lot 3 (Sunset & Hilgard), adjacent to the theater, $8 cash or credit card THE RIGHT POCKET OF THE ROBE (H Dexia Tsepi tou Rasou) Q&A will follow the screening with Thodoris Antoniadis - Actor Greece | 2018 | 93 min Monday, June 3, 7pm @ at UCLA - James Bridges Theater 235 Charles E Young Dr. N  Los Angeles, CA 90095 A lonely monk tries to manage the unbearable sadness and loneliness that suddenly and unexpectedly “return” when he loses his only companion. His dog. Extreme emotions will make him “converse” with his past, and due to this “humble”, for some, trigger, he will reposition his course and his life. Director: Yiannis Lapatas Writer: Stella Vasilantonaki Producer: Artemis productions Cast: Thodoris Antoniadis, Gerasimos Skiadaresis, Lampros Stavrinopoulos, Manos Vakousis

name: 2019-06-29T08:00:00-0700
venue_id: Early identification and intervention are critical for optimizing an infant’s developmental and functional potential. This Neuro-Developmental Baby Treatment course focuses on identification and treatment of infants and toddlers, from birth to two years of age, who have neurological diagnoses or are at risk for neuro-motor problems. Research in movement sciences is drawn upon to enhance clinical reasoning and identify multifaceted and complex influences that impact motor development and motor behavior. Movement observation and analysis skills are emphasized as a basis for ongoing assessment and to inform intervention. A family centered approach to management and intervention, parent education and training is incorporated throughout course using the Neuro-Developmental Treatment (NDT) and management perspective. Participants will practice treatment strategies with each other and on a doll. Patient assessment and treatment demonstrations provide opportunities for clinical application of course material and facilitate group discussions.   Audience: Licensed pediatric occupational therapists, physical therapists and speech-language pathologists and assistants who work with infants and toddlers. Enrollment is limited to 24 participants unless alternative arrangements are made in advance. Level of Instruction: Intermediate   Participant requirements: *Participants must bring a soft bodied “rag doll” ( with approximately 18-24 inches in length. Individually made therapy dolls may be purchased through monamiedolls.com. Please allow sufficient time for order as dolls are individually made.   Lab clothing required: Participants should bring or wear clothes for movement labs that are comfortable and do not restrict movement.   Prerequisite reading recommendations:* Components of Typical and Atypical Motor Development by Lois Bly 2011 available through NDTA at www.ndta.org Baby Treatment Based on NDT Principles by Lois Bly, MA, PT. ISBN:      9780761644507available through Pro-ed. *This information must be stated in advertising and in confirmation letters.   Objectives: Upon completion of this course participants will be able to: Identify complex, multifaceted      influences that contribute to and shape motor development. Apply movement observation and      analysis skills to infants demonstrating typical and atypical development. Identify and test multiple      hypotheses regarding relationships between critical activities,      participation, impairments and contextual factors. Observe and analyze atypical posture and movement      strategies in infants and toddlers. Describe the impact of atypical posture and movement      strategies on functional activities and participation for the present and      future. Apply clinical reasoning to      guide assessment and treatment planning for infants. Practice NDT based treatment      strategies to enhance motor performance in infants and toddlers. Identify and describe early      signs of atypical or at risk posture and movement strategies in infants      that indicate need for intervention.   Schedule* Day 1 8:00 - 12:00     Intro to NDT Baby Treatment                         Development in the first and second quarter                         Movement and Treatment Labs (with dolls) 12:00 - 1:00     Lunch 12:30 – 5:00    Development in the third quarter                         Movement and Treatment Labs                         Early Warning Signs   Day 2 8:00 - 11:30     Development in the fourth quarter                         Movement and Treatments labs 11:30 - 12:30   Lunch 12:30 - 4:00     Assessment and Treatment demonstration                         Movement and Treatments labs                         Parent participation and home management                         Group discussion             * 15-minute breaks are provided during each morning and afternoon session.   Instructor: Lauren Miller Beeler PT, DPT, PCS, C/NDT; NDTA Coordinator Instructor   ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR: Lauren Miller Beeler, PT, DPT, PCS, C/NDT is the founder of South Coast Therapy, a multi-disciplinary, pediatric, out-patient practice, in Orange County, CA. Lauren graduated from Indiana University and has more than 30 years of experience practicing in pediatrics and neurological rehabilitation. Certified as an APTA Board Certified Pediatric Clinical Specialist in 1991, Lauren has a broad clinical background in pediatrics. She is a NDTA Coordinator Instructor for The Neuro-Developmental Treatment/Bobath Certificate Course in the Treatment and Management of Children with Cerebral Palsy and is a NDTA Advanced Course Instructor, with specialty areas in Baby Treatment and Gait. Lauren has been teaching NDT related courses since the early 90’s.

name: 2019-06-01T08:50:00-0700
venue_id: **Please read the entire course description before making a purchase.** COURSE DESCRIPTION According to the American Heart Association, the Heartsaver CPR course is “designed for anyone with little or no medical training who needs a course completion card for job, regulatory, or other requirements.” We highly encourage all members of our community to pursue this basic CPR training, especially those who work in large public places or those who spend much time with multiple age ranges. Students practice as they learn under the observation of the instructors, which allows them to receive feedback and guidance. At the end of the four-hour class, students will need to pass skills examinations for both adult/child and infant CPR to receive their certification. *This course is taught in English Content covered by the course (from AHA): High-quality CPR for adults, children, and infants The AHA Chain of Survival Use of an AED Choking relief for adults, children, and infants REFUND POLICY We will refund your ticket in full if requested at least 48 hours prior to the start of class. Requests for refunds that are not within this time frame will be denied. PARKING INFORMATION The UCLA campus provides a number of pay by space parking lots that are easily accessible. Lots 4, 7, 8 and 9 are all located relatively close to our normal classrooms in Ackerman Union and the Student Activities Center (SAC). These parking lots can be located through any map of UCLA. name: 2019-06-06T12:00:00-0700
venue_id: Heather Rastovac Akbarzadeh, Ph.D.UC Chancellor’s Postdoctoral FellowDepartment of Asian American Studies, UC Davis Do Iranian Dancers Need Saving? Savior Spectatorship and the Production of Iranian Dancers as “Objects of Rescue”Thursday, June 6, 2019 12 p.m. to 1:50 p.m.Kaufman Hall 208 RSVP Requested Because of Iranian state-implemented restrictions on public dance performance, effective since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, diasporic spaces are often constructed as offering Iranian dancers the unconditional freedom to fully realize themselves as artists. In this narrative, Iranian dancers gain agential freedom – a dancer’s subjecthood – only through non-Iranian spaces, whether geographical or familial. In turn, I argue that this account constructs Iranian dancers as what transnational feminist scholar Inderpal Grewal calls “object of rescue.” Building upon transnational feminist analyses on Euro-American (neo)colonial “saving” enterprises, this talk draws critical parallels between the militaristic imperative to “save” Muslim women at the start of the US-led War on Terror and the discursive frameworks that position Iranian dancers as needing to be saved from the Iranian state, their families, or from Islam, which ostensibly forbid them to dance. Drawing on research from my larger book project, the talk focuses specifically on dancer-choreographer Afshin Ghaffarian, who was granted asylum in France in 2009. I analyze the French reception of Ghaffarian's live performances and the American-produced biographical dramatic film, Desert Dancer (2014), which portrays Ghaffarian’s life as an aspiring dancer in Iran and his defection to Paris. I develop a theory of what I call savior spectatorship, a multi-modal kinesthetic looking practice that operates within transmedia environments wherein discourses and images (static and moving) construct Iranian dancers as victims and their Euro-American and diasporic audiences as compassionate saviors. As a pervasive form of twenty-first century cosmopolitan subject formation, I suggest that savior spectatorship is produced and sustained through historical and contemporary sociopolitical power relations and (neo)colonial saving enterprises. My theorizations of savior spectatorship complicate prevalent assumptions that hold active spectatorship and kinesthetic empathy as inherently critical or politically progressive acts of engagement with dance performance. Instead, I interrogate how dance becomes a barometer with which to measure modernity, freedom, and humanity, and how savior spectatorship of Iranian dancers constructs a model of Iranianness that fits all too neatly within Euro-American geopolitical paradigms that position Iran as backward and pre-modern.  Heather Rastovac Akbarzadeh is a UC Chancellor’s Postdoctoral Fellow in UC Davis’s Department of Asian American Studies under the mentorship of Dr. Sunaina Maira. From 2016 – 2018, Heather was the Mellon Postdoctoral Fellow in Dance Studies at Stanford University. She earned her Ph.D. in Performance Studies from UC Berkeley with a Designated Emphasis in Women, Gender, and Sexuality. Heather’s research, which extends upon two decades as a dancer-choreographer among Iranian American communities, examines the lives and artistic works of diasporic Iranian dancers and performance artists residing in North America and Western Europe. Heather engages in ethnography, discourse analysis, and performance analysis to investigate the racialized and gendered economies of Iranian performance in transnational art markets and among diasporic audiences. Her current book project investigates how global War on Terror biopolitics construct Iranian dancers as neoliberal subjects of freedom. An examination of choreographic content, media coverage, and audience reception of performances by diasporic Iranians in North America and Europe reveal how colonial histories of Euro-American “saving” practices are animated through discourses surrounding these dancers and their performances.

external_url: UCLA Herb Alpert School of Music Prospective Student Tour
name: 2019-06-07T15:00:00-0700
venue_id: Join a current School of Music student and/or staff member for a tour of the Schoenberg Music Building and the Evelyn & Mo Ostin Music Center, where you’ll see our performance spaces, classrooms, recording studio, rehearsal rooms, practice rooms, computer labs, and more!  Learn about the programs in our Music, Ethnomusicology, and Musicology departments, hear about student life in the School of Music, and get answers to your questions about the application process.   Reservations are required for tours, and space is limited.  Prospective students may bring up 3 guests with them.  For groups larger than 4, please contact admissions@schoolofmusic.ucla.edu.   Tours will meet on the steps leading to the Schoenberg Hall entrance of the Schoenberg Music Building, just east of Portola Plaza.  If you are in the right place, you will be able to see the Music Library through large windows on one side and Dickson Court South on the other side.  A sign will indicate that the School of Music tours begins here, and your tour guide will meet you there at the start of the tour.  The closest parking structure is Lot 2, on the corner of Westholme and Hilgard Avenue.  You can purchase a parking day-pass at the kiosk off of Westholme and Hilgard Avenue or use a Pay-By-Space Station in the parking structure. Please refer to the following resources for additional information about getting to UCLA and parking on campus: https://schoolofmusic.ucla.edu/visit/  http://www.ucla.edu/maps-directions-parking/ For more information about the UCLA Herb Alpert School of Music, please visit schoolofmusic.ucla.edu.  If you have any questions, please contact admissions@schoolofmusic.ucla.edu.

name: 2019-06-01T13:00:00-0700
venue_id: Explore our living museum featuring collections of plants from around the globe! Join a docent for a free guided tour of the garden on the first Saturday of the month at 1pm. We’ll hear the stories of a selection of plants in the garden, and their relevance to human society. All ages are welcome. See you there! We will meet at the La Kretz Garden Pavilion at the northern end of the garden. Restrooms are available there. If you have a group of 10+ people interested in a private tour, please fill out this online form and we can arrange that for you rather than attending a drop-in tour. There is no parking available at the Garden. Visitors can park in UCLA Parking Structure 2 (payment required) near the Westholme Avenue entrance to campus, or at metered parking spots in Westwood. Metered street parking can also be found on Manning Ave, which can be accessed from Charles E. Young Drive or Hilgard Avenue. The address of the UCLA La Kretz Garden Pavilion is 707 Tiverton Dr. Los Angeles, CA 90095.

external_url: KPFK Speaker Series: Thom Hartmann on The Hidden History of Guns and the Second Amendment
name: 2019-06-22T14:30:00-0700
venue_id: Join Thom Hartmann for a unique deep dive exploration into the vast arc of the history of slave patrols and the Second Amendment. How guns facilitated the most massive genocide in history which happened right here on this continent, and how the Second Amendment has been twisted and distorted by the Supreme Court and the gun manufacturers into something that the founders would never have recognized. Thom will also explain what we can do about the gun crisis in the United States, what other countries have done, and what we can learn from it, and lay out the forces arrayed against us that we have to either bring to our way of thinking or simply defeat at the polls to keep ourselves and our children safe. Thom Hartmann is a nationally syndicated radio and TV host. He’s a four-time recipient of the Project Censored Award and is a New York Times bestselling author of 24 books in print, translated into many languages.  Stephanie Miller is an American political commentator, comedian, and host of The Stephanie Miller Show. She will host Thom for the event with a question and answer segment.

external_url: THEATER Tour for Prospective Students - Jun 3
name: 2019-06-03T14:30:00-0700
venue_id: (This is a THEATER Department Tour.  Please check other dates for Film Department Tours.) The UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television (TFT) is the only school in the country where the study of theater, film, television and digital media is integrated within a single professional school.  TFT draws on industry leaders for its faculty, advisors and mentors.  Our undergraduate programs are ranked first out of 500 programs nationally (Princeton Review/Gourman Report). During your tour, you will get a behind the scenes peek at our first rate facilities.  For the Film Tour, this includes our sound stages and television studios.  For the Theater Tour, this includes the prop shop, scene shop, costume shop, and theaters. Reservations are required for all tours, as space and dates are limited.  Note: due to performances, rehearsals, and classes - guests on tours may not be able to go into some rooms. We limit tours to only ten people.  Each prospective student may bring only one guest for a total of TWO tickets.  If bringing a guest, please reserve two tickets. Check-in for the tours is in our Student Services Office - 103 East Melnitz Hall.   For directions to East Melnitz Hall, please visitwww.tft.ucla.edu/about/map. PARKING: Purchase a day-pass at the kiosk off of Westholme & Hilgard Avenue or use a Pay-By-Space Station.  Use Parking Lot 3, located near the cross streets of Hilgard & Sunset. https://main.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors    For information about our academic programs, please visit our website at www.tft.ucla.edu/admissions.    If you have any questions, need to cancel, or need to change your reservation for this event - please contact us by phone at (310) 206-8441.

name: 2019-06-18T08:00:00-0700
venue_id: UCLA Staff Assembly presents: Inaugural Invest in U Summit Tuesday, June 18, 2019 8:00 am – 3:00 pm Carnesale Commons Open to all UCLA staff Registration: $55     Staff Assembly is excited to announce its inaugural Invest in U Summit taking place on June 18, 2019 at Carnesale Commons. Join us for discussions designed to support staff in finding a balance within personal and professional development. This conference is focused on addressing personal growth and career advancement by bringing together keynote speakers representing UC Office of the President and our very own UCLA Leadership, along with a variety of breakout sessions led by dynamic experts sharing their knowledge and tools in a workshop setting, followed by a campus resource fair featuring university resources available for staff. Our goal is to inspire you to become the best version of yourself thanks to the opportunities UCLA has to offer. Essentially: we encourage our staff to invest in YOU and invest in U"CLA. We hope you can join us for this groundbreaking experience! Distinguished Presenters: Joe Bristow
column19: UCLA Campus Human Resources Jerry Kang
column24: UCLA Health Human Resources Sherry Main
column26: UC Santa Cruz ...and several more! Breakout Session topics include: Career Planning & Development Music Therapy / Managing Stress Financial Management Public Speaking *Breakout session attendance will be selected day of. We encourage participants to arrive at 8am to check-in
column27: select their preferred/available breakout session options and participate in the networking activities that will be available to meet other staff who are focused and dedicated to investing in U.   More information about the agenda will be available soon. Follow us on Facebook and Instagram @uclasa for updates! Please contact staffassembly@ucla.edu if you would like to pay by recharge. We will process the payment shortly after the Summit. Space is limited so sign up and tell your colleagues about this opportunity now!"

external_url: Celebrate Your Graduation at UCLA Faculty Center
name: 2019-06-13T17:30:00-0700
venue_id: Celebrate Graduation 2019 at the UCLA Faculty Center! Come to the UCLA Faculty Center for a gourmet buffet-style meal to celebrate your graduation! Join us before or after the ceremony - We are conveniently located on the eastern edge of the campus, not too far away from most Convocation sites.   You can start off your evening with cocktails in our midcentury style Cypress Bar and Lounge, then segue into one of our specially decorated banquet rooms for a sumptuous buffet. You are free to make arrangements to customize with your own decorations and balloons as well!   A full range of food options is sure to delight you and your guests. Buffet options will include soup, salad, roasted meats, pasta, fish, vegetarian options, and decadent desserts! Please let us know of any dietary restrictions - we can accommodate! Students and Guests: $54.95 Children (12 & under): $24.95 Children (5 & under): Free   FAQs What are my parking options for this event? The nearest parking structure is #2, located on the eastern side of the campus. If you do not have a Bruin parking permit, please go to the Parking Kiosk or Visitor Parking on the lower level of the structure. What can I bring into the event? You are welcome to make arrangements with us to bring decorations, but no confetti, outside food or drinks are allowed. How can I contact the organizer with any questions? Please call 310.825.0877 and ask for Eileen, Elizabeth or Athena. You can also email at club@ucla.edu. What's the refund policy? Exchanges and/or refunds are only allowed one week before your reserved date. Cancellations or no-shows will be billed in full on the date of the event. Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event? Please bring the printed ticket or a screenshot for your event. Can I update my registration information? You may update your registration up to a week before your event. Please contact us if you encounter any problems or have questions. Is my registration fee or ticket transferrable? Sorry, no. Please contact us at least 7 days before your event to make any changes. Is it ok if the name on my ticket or registration doesn't match the person who attends? As tickets are non-transferrable, the name on the ticket must match the name of the person hosting the event. Are Eventbrite fees and tax included in the price of the ticket? No, these are added on to the price of each ticket. California Sales Tax of 9.5% will be added to the ticket price. The Eventbrite fee ranges from $3.45 to $5.44 for each ticket, depending on the price.

external_url: Support Group with the Adolescent Epilepsy Center UCLA
name: 2019-06-06T18:00:00-0700
venue_id: Come join us on the first thursday of every month for an adolescent and parent support group.  Support Group Meeting Details AEC Support Group MeetingWhen: Thursday, April 4th, 20196:00 pm to 8:00 pm (try to come a little early so we can start on time - don't forget about LA traffic!)Where: 300 Medical Plaza First meet in room 3200, Marissa Leaf on the third floor Los Angeles, CA 90095   Who: Adolescents ages 12-22 living with Epilepsy and their parents   The support group is a two hour meeting. We will meet all together to begin, and then split into groups to allow the teens and parents privacy during the support group meeting. The meeting will be held in conference room 3200 on the third floor of 300 Medical Plaza.  Take the main elevators up to the third floor.  Once you get out of the elevator, turn right and walk forward to the Marrisa Leaf room with the double doors.   Signs will be posted on the door as well. Please email us at uclateenepilepsy@mednet.ucla.edu. You can discover more about our clinic at https://www.uclahealth.org/mattel/adolescent-epilepsy/.  We hope to see you at the meeting! Madison Harris, OTD and Amy Slavin, MSW

external_url: Free Real Estate Intro Session - Westwood
name: 2019-06-03T10:00:00-0700
venue_id: Kick start your professional Real Estate career with a free introductory session. CA Realty Training is partnering with Keller Williams Realty to provide you an intensive introduction into Real Estate — absolutely FREE. You will receive a comprehensive breakdown on: How to get your Real Estate License Real Estate topics and terminology to excel your performance The first few chapters of the course textbook that’s packed with valuable, inside knowledge. The training sessions are run by successful real estate agents with veteran level experience in the industry as well as training high performing real estate agents. If you would like to continue with the full 3-month training program, enrollment is required. However, the first session is completely FREE. With a free introductory course, there’s absolutely no reason not to start your lucrative career in Real Estate - we’ll teach you everything you need to know to do it. Learn more about our Real Estate School in Westwood. name: 2019-06-08T20:00:00-0700
venue_id: Please join us on Saturday, June 8, to celebrate the opening of Sarah Lucas: Au Naturel, the first American survey of one of the UK’s most influential artists. Be among the first to see the exhibition while you enjoy artistic cocktails and bites by Audrey at the Hammer. Exhibitions also on view are Celebration of Our Enemies: Selections from the Hammer Contemporary Collection, Hammer Projects: Andrea Fraser, Hammer Projects: Yunhee Min, and Hammer Projects: Tschabalala Self. This event is free and open to the public—no ticket or check-in is required. RSVP does not guarantee entry once the museum reaches capacity. For Hammer MembersTo receive priority entry and a free first drink, please bring your member card and check in at the welcome desk in the Wilshire Lobby starting at 8 p.m. Not a Member?Join today and bring your confirmation email with you on Saturday to access the member line and your new benefits. Join at the Immerse level ($250) or higher to attend the Director’s Reception before the public celebration. Parking DetailsLimited parking is available at the museum, $7 cash only. Additional event parking is available at 11020 Kinross Ave (UCLA Parking Lot 36) with a flat rate of $5 payable by credit card/cash at the pay station or pay by cell phone through the Park Mobile app. We encourage visitors to consider biking, public transportation, or ride-sharing. By RSVPing to this event, you will be signed up for the Hammer's mailing list. You may opt out at any time. Image: Sarah Lucas, Self-portrait with Fried Eggs, 1996. © Sarah Lucas. Courtesy Sadie Coles HQ, London

name: 2019-06-17T09:00:00-0700
venue_id: University of California AI in Biomedicine Conference Please join us this summer for this first-of-its-kind meeting focused on the application of Artificial Intelligence methods to topics in biology, health, and medicine across the entire University of California system. Affiliates from ALL UC CAMPUSES are welcome. Presentations will feature efforts taking place across the University of California, however we will be joined by a small number of external speakers including: Jeff Dean, PhDLead, Google AI Suchi Saria, PhDJohn C. Malone Assistant ProfessorDepartments of Computer Science, Applied Math & Statistics, and Health Policy & ManagementDirector, Machine Learning and Healthcare LabJohns Hopkins University Wendy Nilsen, PhDProgram Director, Smart and Connected Health, Computer & Information Science & EngineeringNational Science Foundation More details can be found on the event webpage: uc-ai-biomedicine.org Poster presentations are now being accepted via the Poster Submission Web formSubmissions are due by 5/31/19 Day 1 : Practice of AI in Biomedicine Opening Remarks from UC Office of the President Featured Keynote: Jeff Dean Presenter Panel: Fostering the connection - Data generators & AI researchers  Presenter Panel: AI in Healthcare Panel: UC Leadership - Opportunities & challenges for AI in Biomedicine Featured Keynote: Suchi Saria Presenter Panel: AI in foundational sciences Poster Reception Day 2 : Strengthening UC Capabilities Opening Remarks from UC Health Panel: Common/shared data, systems, and tools Panel: Responsible use of AI in Biomedicine Panel: Training, growing, and retaining talent Featured Keynote: Wendy Nilsen Extended Networking Lunch
